posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
went to a funeral with my then girlfriend in japan
her grandma was apparently some famous person, family had 2 katanas from the emperor, many medals and such for the family's research in botany
anyway, there was a dinner in the grandma's honour before the urn was placed in the familial crypt
as i was the partner of my girlfriend, i too was in the front podium thing at the head of the room, with the other ~100 guests sitting below us. we were facing all the guests as if we were a panel
>the food
they brought everyone a grey cube on a plate, along with beer. nobody ate, every SINGLE fucking person was staring at me, and my gf's uncle leaned over and informed me that they were all waiting for me to take the first bite
>grey jelly cube
>little bits throughout it, slightly opaque
>take a corner out of it with my spoon, briefly smell it
>smells like nothing
>put it in my mouth
>very cold, soggy
>chew
>crunchy and hard and weird exploding seawater chunks
>fucking revolting, eyes literally start to water
>have to gulp it down with a swig of beer
>everyone starts riotously laughing and everyone digs in
turns out it was some ancient traditional dish from that region of japan. basically they catch a fish, then chop it up whole and turn it into a jello cube using the seawater they caught it in. it's literally a jello cube of fish scales, bones, random ocean debris, and fish organ slime

the most disgusting food i have ever eaten by a huge margin, borderline inedible, and i will eat anything

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18900142
That's the same across all chocolate around the globe because the third world countries where cocao is harvested, packaged, stored, and then sold to overseas buyers is often in not so clean conditions. And processors in the first world countries can't exactly find and remove these impurities once they're there.
If you're this germaphobic then you must never eat fruits and vegetables since they grow in the ground and have dirt residue on them.

And those are just the limits, it's not like it's saying all chocolate has that much filth in it, whereas all chocolate in the EU has vegetable oil.

You should also look into lead content in chocolate, because nearly all chocolate has lead in it, and that's just because of the soil that cacao is grown in, not because of the processors who turn it into chocolate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
An egg dumplings recipe that my mother got from her grandmother which originated from either Germany or Russia. Can't remember where exactly. Simply take a couple eggs, a couple tablespoons of milk and cup or 2 of flour, beat the eggs and milk together, add flour and beat until thick, scoop out some portions and throw them into boiling water pot and cook for 15-30 minutes. When done cooking scoop out dumplings with spoon with a strainer to remove water and put in bowl applying butter and pepper to your liking.

Been thinking about changing the recipe up abit and adding more too it but I think it's pretty peak poor people food as is.

Cereal, instant ramen, homemade pizzas using the cheapest pizza dough mix, jarred sauce, and store brand cheese available, canned ravioli, spaghetti-os, sandwiches, everything the cheapest possible off-brand from the discount grocery store that only sold whatever cheap shit they could get that week.

I was fully aware how shit our situation was from a pretty young age, decided when I moved out I wasn't going to do that shit anymore and started teaching myself to cook immediately.

Two embarrassing stories, our school had some kind of park outing. They ordered those giant 9 foot subway sandwiches for the class. Everyone was supposed to chip in a couple of dollars but my brother and I had nothing so we had to eat our pb&j sandwiches while all the other kids feasted.
Second one I was spending the day at a friends house. They decide to go out to dinner to some pizza place. Told me it was a family thing and I could come along but couldn't eat with them I had to buy my own food.
Now that I think about it that family were kind of assholes. That wasn't the first time they fucked with me. They knew we were dirt poor and they were rich. Probably why they never let me hang out with their kid again after that.
Being a poor kid living in a relatively well off neighborhood was hell. Everyone I knew at school/church was always going on ski trips and shit and we never got to go along with anything.

i wasn't particularly poor myself but my parents both grew up either very poor or in a family massive enough to have to worry about food costs between so many kids. as a result they continued a habit as adults of buying the absolute lowest priced value foods to the cent they could find even though they never needed to by the time me or my brother were old enough to care. they were actually really resourceful when it came to cooking so the food was good but occasionally i got some unfortunate stuff such as

>meat frozen so long it tasted like nothing by the time we did eat it
>the occasional expired dollar store food, never understood this because there was a legitimate grocery store literally next door with comparable prices
>mom would always yell at me for taking a pack of 2 poptarts instead of just 1 to school at age 13, where my morning was basically leaving the house at 5am for a long ass bus trip and no school lunch until noon
>incredibly low amounts of salt or spices ever used, didn't grasp this until it clicked why homemade plain chicken tasted nothing like restaurant chicken
>yelling over who opened a cereal
>yelling over who finished a pack of anything, but also yelling over who left a small amount of a pack of anything
>insistence that the same coffee grounds be reused, i thought coffee was just shit water until adulthood because this was obviously not good
>the occasional bizarre leftovers creation that was hit or miss, later learned that this was usually a result of my dad being bored. he still does this to this day and it's usually something pretty cool nowadays but he holds himself to such a high standard and expectations for what amounts to "mix of whatever is in the fridge"

however there was some stuff i really did like that i still eat now that im on my own, like cheap frozen fish and pierogis.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Not poor but I'm a social worker.
I've seen three "types" of home, in the first three family has some money but is dysfunctional, all the food is junk food, the freezer is full of pizza, the fridge is full of soft drink. This isn't nearly as expensive as you might imagine because of how calorie dense these foods acrually are. Kids skip meals, throw tantrums when food runs out, binge eat, get fat.

In the second type of home there's no money but at least one tired and stressed family member cooks. Often it's monotonous and totally unseasoned, boiled frozen vegetables, pasta, boiled eggs. Meat offcuts or frozen hotdogs in a pan, boiled potatoes. There's a variant for every ethnicity, but this is actually far better nutrition wise.

Third household is begging and stealing, everyone hoards and hides food, the only things in the fridge are moldy or fouled.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18881748
Buy in bulk, even cheaper brands are fine even if they don't taste as much. They also last very long so you're not wasting any of it.
The money I save by buying slightly less quality meat for a month can be used to buy said oils and spices that will last several months so when you got that down upgrade meat as budget allows. We're not talking about a full cabinet of 20 spices either, just the most basic ones. I'm assuming salt and pepper are not included so rosemary, thyme, oregano, chili and one or two more after preference. Obviously you can't expect getting fresh stuff constantly unless planting it yourself.

I just know I'd prefer more basic meals with a larger choice of spices and oils to make variations than simply upgrading the meat quality slightly and not having said stuff. Worst case you can get piece by piece as budget allows since it, again, lasts very long (oils and spices).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18876648
Grew up fairly poor, 2 children single mom on teacher salary. I don't think there was really any consistent thread to what we ate. Mom cooked the vast majority of meals, either from scratch or instant, and we didn't eat much meat. The stuff she'd make from scratch was mostly soups and stews, and we ate a lot of rice and vegetables. We still could eat at mcdonalds or get pizza sometimes, but it was uncommon enough that it felt like a treat when we did. If there was anything that was missing it's snacks. She'd never buy soda, juice, cookies, or chips with the groceries. The only time we'd get a dessert after a meal is if we went to subway she'd get a single cookie to split between the three of us. If I went to a friend's house and they had snacks and sodas it seemed like the height of luxury. All in all I think she did a really good job since I only really realized how poor we were looking back on it. Even though she wasn't the greatest cook, food anxiety was never an issue for us and we developed fairly healthy eating habits.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18876648
We grew up rich but had to eat poor. We even had to help out with the cooking. We never got fast food, popcorn, cola, chips, sandwiches from Subway, Starbucks coffee or ketchup from a bottle (exceptions were Christmas, Easter, and our anniversaries in July and August). We had to help plant, reap, peel and pickle onions, leek, cornichons, make pig stews, sausages and candy with paws, ears, tails and blood. We had to learn which fish and shellfish are in season and how to peel, fillet and batter them.

To this day I spend 1/10th per month on food of what poor people spend (source: /ck/). Yet I eat like ancient European nobility (source: nunya).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mum did her best raising 5 kids by herself, and we had food on the table which is more than a lot can say so I'd never complain about it especially now. She put herself through medical school to become a nurse to provide for us, she was hard working and I appreciate everything she did.

We ate a LOT of "spaghetti" though which was just noodles with store brand ragu on top, to this day even good spaghetti makes me cringe a little. Fish sticks, microwaved taco sticks, all that shit - even passing by it in the grocery store makes me feel uncomfortable.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18876648
Pajeet Canadian. My family was poor but we ate three full meals a day plus some goyslop. Rarely ever ordered takeout, maybe 2 slices of pizza or 3 donuts once every few weeks that we would share between the 6 of us.

Dinner was a fresh beef/chicken curry and fresh white rice. When we got really broke, no meat curry, it was tuna mixed into Dahl (lentil soup). Often with lettuce and cucumbers. And apple juice (a 2L can was a $1).

Lunch the next day was leftover dinner but the curry would be reheated with a cup of water mixed in so it was wateryyyy. The curry was made thin originally too. So we got like two ounces of meat per meal max.

Lunch packed for school was a strawberry jam sandwich.

My family was never poor, but we were definitely the poorest kids in a school filled with the very wealthy. I remember not wanting kids over at my house once I realized that we were not living on the same level at all. And then having to hear about their amazing vacations while I went to see my grandma every summer, the crazy setups they'd have for TV and consoles, the activities and access they had to things I'd fantasize about. I was quite lucky in the sense that only a few people would make fun of you for that though.

I definitely appreciated the huge windfall of money in those red pockets come Chinese New Year though (grew up in SE Asia, this is a thing). And being friends with some of them gave me access to things I couldn't have otherwise (country clubs, events, boating etc). Rich kids have plenty of perks if you're on good terms with them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18884341
ok, first I chuckled, but then I realized you're not trolling, so lets break it down, shall we?
>fry some onions and garlic in butter
first of all, not some onions, but you caramelize onions.
second, not some garlic, but garlic and ginger, and you do these separetely, only for around 30 seconds or so, otherwise you will burn them.
And no, not butter, but ghee. If you don't have ghee, use regular oil, don't use butter, lol.
>add curry powder and let it combine and cook for a bit
wait, actually good advice? well, almost. for 500g of meat I recommend 2 tablespoons of good quality curry powder, but actually I recommend adding around 200ml of passata, cooking it for a couple of minutes, and then adding spices, which then you cook a bit more to get out their true flavours.
>add milk
for krishna's sake, never, absolutely, n e v e r add milk.
add chicken, then when no longer pink, dilute everything with a bit of water
>Then finish cooking seared chicken in it (thighs work great)
total gibberish, I'm not even bother deciphering it, it does says chicken though, so no, that's the wrong time to put the chicken in.
thighs do work great though. 5 points for slytherin (that's where I imagine you would be after writing such low quality recipe)
>Let the chicken simmer in there for 30 minutes
wtf, I love dry mushy chicken? just kidding, give it 20 minutes top.
>The curry powder thickens the sauce by itself so you don't have to do anything else to it.
o boy, there we go. curry powder will not thicken the sauce whatsoever. not even a bit, nope, runny, watery, curry on your way sir!
remember that mythical passata we added earlier? yep, that's your main thickener.
>Pile it on rice and w'Allah
first of all, you forgot to add a little bit of heavy cream, just a tad to mellow the spices.
and second of all, no, don't pile it on rice, pour it into a bowl and add a bit at the time on your rice platter, next to the rice. you want easy access to plain rice to cleanse the palette.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18884388
So to clarify you could put basically any combo of these ingredients and make a curry dish, probably by order of my listing. Honestly just looking at it, it's probably correct to assume greatest to smallest by volume added to the average dish.

If you already cook a decent amount you should have nearly all of this in your spice cabinet and fridge. Practice by looking up a few recipes, aloo gobi, aloo palak, saag paneer, vindaloo, etc. Then you'll get a sense for "this type of curry uses more cardamom" or "sri lankan curries use way more ground coriander:" Then once you cook a few of these and understand the flavor profiles you can cook basically any dish like that by feel. It's also wild because it actually shares a lot in common with many mexican dishes and chinese food. Idk why people try to make shit so complicated.

posts.com:
>>18885145
>jaggery is just sugar, black salt is just salt, hing tastes like shallots/onions
Wrong on every fucking count. Jaggery is sugar in the same sense that brown sugar is the same as white sugar. Black salt is mostly salt, but has a much different taste due to the other stuff in it and is not a good salt substitute. The flavor of hing is vaguely onion like, but the texture sure isn't like an onion's. You might as well say minced garlic and onion powder are the same.

While most of the things I listed are in garam masala, you're not going to be able to temper right without whole spices, and for that you're going to want things like whole cloves, whole cumin seeds, cinnamon, etc.

In conclusion, deal with it!

>>18885123
The sauce that makes up the curry is usually a very thick pureed vegetable stock made from onions, garlic, carrots, tomato and bell peppers that spices are then added to. The meat or veg of the dish is usually fried in ghee with a garlic & ginger puree, has about a tablespoon of whatever spice mixture is required for the dish and then 1/4 cup of condensed tomato paste and a couple of ladles of that vegetable stock are added in until they get the right consistency/colour. There's a lot more veg in an Indian curry than almost any other kind of takeaway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18889540
Darker roasts will offgas very quickly, but the exposed surface oils will oxidize and go rancid just as quickly. Thats the skunky stale smell you get from grocery store bags. Spoiled plant fat doesn't taste good, drink those within a month off roasting. Anything lighter than that will be fine a good while longer if you're not constantly getting in the bag exposing it to fresh oxygen. Thats where shit like airscape containers(anything sealed with a one way valve really) come in handy. You're not letting fresh oxygen react with the roasted plant fats inside your beans, while letting them vent carbon dioxide. co2 doesn't taste good. Thats why you stir crema on espresso into the shot. Its a sour bitter layer of trapped gasses preventing you from getting to the actual flavors you're trying to extract. Resting will depend on the roast and density of the bean. There's no harm in testing how they taste once a week, just avoid constant exposure to fresh oxygen. Also why people like the meme single dosing tubes.
https://www.wired.com/2009/10/your-tongue-the-carbon-dioxide-sensor/

Some beans are more chaffy than others. I find that larger beans and washed coffees have more chaff. Grind coarseness wouldn't have anything to do with how much chaff a coffee has. It may be slightly larger flakes with a coarser grind, but there won't be any less of it if you were to grind finer.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18889137
Buy what you can drink within 2-4 weeks. By the time roasted coffee gets to you it has rested enough. Coffee is rested for 1-3 days after roasting for the flavors to develop. Do not confuse this with the spergy weeks-long CO2 off-gassing espresso dorks do. They do this so that they can more precisely dial in their shots at the expense of losing flavor. I repeat: they are losing flavor as a trade off for replicability of espresso shot extraction. The volatile aromatic compounds that give good, fresh coffee its taste are lost over time. It is very noticeable after about 2-4 weeks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Where is the line you draw when it comes to buying certain ingredients vs preparing/growing other ingredients from home?
How many of you truly prefer strictly home made fresh ingredients or do you make some exceptions and say fuck it and buy bulk/pre packaged ingredients from the store?
If you're okay with the latter, do you make exceptions for imported/higher quality costly ingredients or just buy whatever's most convenient in the moment?
I'm kinda new to cooking since it's something I've been trying when I started dieting a few months back and I'll be honest and say I usually take the convenience over having to prepare certain ingredients, although I'm interested in possibly making my own burger buns once I start making my own smash burgers, but outside of just trying it once to see how comfortable I am with it, I imagine it'll be a one off experiment that may turn out well enough but maybe I won't personally engage in every time I make burgers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
There's no hard defined "line" as much as knowing what your weaknesses are when it comes to cooking things yourself, or what's just not suitable for you in your situation at home like not having special equipment or enough workspace, time, ect.

For example, bread made by someone else is always better than the bread I can make myself at home because I'm just not that good at baking bread. I still bake bread myself sometimes for fun and to improve, but more often than not if I want a decent loaf of bread I'll just buy one and I'm okay with that, and I know where to get really fucking good bread.

This thinking can be applied to nearly all ingredients and cooking. If you know your limitations and shortcomings, there's no problem with just buying what is available to you conveniently and quickly.

You can still make attempts at improve your cooking skills in the meantime of course, getting better at making certain things slowly but surely. Practice makes better.

If you want to learn how to cook, filmmaker Robert Rodriguez gave really good advice: think of your five most favorite foods, and just learn how to cook those five things, and learn how to cook them really well. Eventually you'll get the hang of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18878544
>Any recommendations from /ck/?
make your own
a bulk pack of dried ramen and a can of vegeta only takes 5 minutes + however long it takes to get the water boiling (and costs far less per serve than packets of instant), and you can improve it from there by making stock yourself, using fresh meat or vegetables, a splash of soy sauce or hoisin or some other sauce, aroma oils etc.
It's also less wasteful since you aren't throwing away massive amounts of plastic wrapping, foil sauce packets.
Once you start making your own you'll quickly realise how oily and artificial the instant ramens are.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Been working at a place off and on for the last 4 years(covid and having a serious medical issue made it so it was more like 2 ACTUAL years of regular shifts).
Notice my raises were all but erased because of a minimum wage going up(Started off with the manager saying all line cooks start at $2 over minimum wage, and get raises every 9-12 months based on performance. Because of covid i never got the last 2 evaluations). Since then minimum wage has gone up by $1.85 cents.
New hires are actually paid more than me, even though i literally had to show one how to use a fucking thermometer last time i worked with him.
Tip-outs was also really exaggerated, with the manager saying it averages around $2/hr for BoH. At best, i did maybe $2.20/hr, but prob 80% of the time its around $1/hr.

Pretty fucking demoralized desu. I'm thinking of just handing in my notice tomorrow. I'm also given shitty shifts(like both opening shifts on the weekend. Something that i guess only a few other guys are trained to do.) that are impossible to offload and would cripple the business if i did a no-show.
I'll admit i'm probably one of the weaker cooks there if you only look at the people who are actually fully trained, but i'v never missed a day or came in late, never take breaks(so many other guys just fuck-off for smoke breaks or disappear in the bathroom for 20 minutes. I made it a point to not use the bathroom unless i literally need to) and have stayed past the end of my shift if asked.
I know its a shitty industry to work in, and i have said so myself plenty of times, but when i actually took a moment to reflect on it when i got my tax papers for it, it really hit me just how exploited i feel from working there.

At my place, we'd make i think 18L every 3 or 4 days, and keep it in a big cambro in the cooler. At the start of the day we'd heat up enough to fill a 1/3rd tray and keep it in a steamwell, and add to it if needed.

I also worked at a place that would portion it out in 10oz bags, and re-heat(in the microwave) to order. Steam well works better since its uniformly warm and for some stuff you need to put it in a pipping bag anyway, so having it portioned in a plastic bag is just wasteful and extra hassle.

Never worked as a line cook, but I did briefly work at a factory that made frozen tv dinners and hot meals for Meals on Wheels, and cafeterias too. The guy that hooked me up with the job told me it was hard work, but the part he left out was just the INSANE amount of mental math I'd have to be constantly doing in order to make sure that the portions were equal....they were very adamant about perfect portions. I couldn't keep up. I mean it was like some dude would just walk past me and say 8 grapes for 37 and place a basket of freshly washed grapes in front of me and expect me to scoop out exactly 296 grapes in less than 30 seconds. There was other shit too like placing scoops of PERFECTLY measured rice into trays that were moving on a conveyer belt at the speed of light, and about 30 minutes into that the rice scooper felt like it weighed 500 lbs.....and there were motherfuckers doing that shit for like 12 hours straight. I never looked at a tv dinner the same way after that job.

Last place I worked 2 best dishes were probably a seafood/cream sauce pasta and lamb chops

>Pasta
>garlic and olive oil into pan with 6 shrimp and 3 scallops, as well as 6 cherry tomatoes, season, add butter
>get the scallops browned on both sides and almost fully cooked and remove from pan, remove shrimp as well
>deglaze pan with white wine, add 12 mussels and heavy cream, season and let reduce to a thick sauce, add back the reserved seafood, add linguine, plate the noodles than add the seafood and mussels to the top, add parsley and parmesan

>Lamb Chops
>pre-marinated
>add to grill and get them marked nicely and cooked to whatever temperature (med rare, etc)
>remove and plate on lemon potatoes and whatever veg we're doing that day

Both were good to eat. The pasta dish was a pain to do 4 or 5 or 6 at a time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18900039
You could make/use a bucket still.
They're pretty cheap and easy to make, you just need two buckets, a big one and a smaller one, a spacer to keep between the two and a heating element like pic related.
Drill a hole in the lid for the big bucket, fish the heating element cable through it, put the spacer in the bottom of the big bucket, fill the smaller bucket with your luquid of choice and put it on top of the spacer, stick the heating element in the smaller bucket, close the lid and let it run for a few days.
The distilled liquid will gather in the bottom of the big bucket.

here's what I do

>pre heat pan for a couple of minutes
>add a small coating of oil to the hot pan
>heat it to the point where the oil is lightly smoking. this polymerizes the oil to form a non-stick cooking surface similar to seasoning cast iron
>remove pan from heat and let it cool down to correct temp for cooking

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Roughly 100% of the time people who can't use stainless without shit sticking when they don't want it to are just unfamiliar with how to control their heat properly. If you're following a recipe you can't just take heat levels they tell you at face value because every stove's output is different. What the author calls medium heat might be closer to low on your stove, or higher, you just kind of have to feel it out and get used to it. For searing meats you generally want the heat about as high as you can get it without burning your cooking fat on contact, but for some things you might need a gentler heat and you'll often need to adjust as you go. Watch videos of people cooking the things you want to make and pay attention to the visual and auditory cues when they add things to the pan or when they adjust their heat and learn to understand what you're looking for. Chef John is pretty good at showing this kinda stuff.

Make sure it's heated before you put food in. If you put a couple drops of water, the droplets should retain their shape if it's properly heats. If the droplets just sizzle and evaporate, it's not hot enough. Then just make sure you use enough fat (butter, oil, lard, etc.). egg producers in every country (and even in local regions) carefully control the diet of their chickens in order to get the color of eggs that the locals expect. they do this by adding or limiting the amount of beta carotene in the chicken feed. THAT'S IT THAT'S ALL!

grocery store eggs could be made dark orange or even red if they wanted. color has no bearing on where eggs were produced.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18898079
IMO, it's one of the few 'prepper' type things that's actually worth it, but only if you breed your own chicks and have a sufficiently large breeding program in place. You need a minimum of 30 chickens, split into three flocks (1 rooster per flock, 9 hens). This is called 'spiral breeding'. You could probably get by with less, but flocks of 30 have gone on for hundreds of years with no issues arising from inbreeding.

Then, if SHTF, you can sell chicks and be a king. Like me, right now, during this egg crisis. If you're dependent on others for sourcing chicks, you're not as independent and robust against price hikes. But getting started with a small flock for learning is a great idea. And if you only have room for 10 chickens, maybe you can find a couple local friends or chicken raisers who want to take part in the spiral breeding program and house the remaining 10-20.

I'd recommend a good dual purpose bird like a beilefelder, bresse, etc, since you'll be culling and eating your subpar roos under this program.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18877773
I came up with the idea for Peat Monster, nice to see it mentioned here. The first batch was a 50/50 blend of Caol Ila and Clynelish (or maybe Ardmore, it was a long time ago lol), both about 10 or 15 years old, aged in ex-bourbon, and bottled at cask strength. It was just called Monster. John Glaser, the founder, didn’t want to make it at first because he didn’t personally enjoy peaty whisky. It turned out to be the blend that put him on the map, so he decided to make it regular production item as Peat Monster, with some water added to lower the proof.

posts.com:
There are two dimensions to alcohol tolerance. One is physiological, one psychological. If you have 80 IQ, you probably have very low psych tolerance. It wont take you much to start acting drunk. If you are 100 lbs soaking wet, or have half a liver, you have no physical tolerance. It wont take much to get you drunk. Now, obviously people can have one problem or the other. For me, im physically very lightweight, but have extraordinary mental tolerance. You need to evaluate your weakness and accomodate. Gain wieght, or start paying attention to your health. You cant magically increase your IQ or "g" to make yourself more resilient, but some mental training might help. Not really a job for /ck/, try /fit/ or /x/ really. Have fun.

>>18893872

Yucatecan is my favorite Mexican regional cuisine. It's alot of citrus, habanero, interesting colors, balancing between bright citrus and spicy with earthy annatto and deep black charred produce, seafood, and the infamous cocinita pibil. Some yucatecan deep cuts are sikil pak (it's like a roasted habanero pumpkin seed salsa with the consistency of hummus), xni pec (pink fruity habanero salsa), Recado negro (black habanero salsa made out of burned chiles and tortillas), panuchos/salbutes (puffy tostada/tacos stuffed with beans), and huaraches (Mexican flat breads)

>>18888686
Somalis eat a banana with literally every dish. It's weird, but primitive countries generally don't have a rigid distinction between sweet and savoury dishes the way they do. In some regions of Uganda, boiled bananas are their staple carb, they eat dishes such as boiled bananas with beans.

Another weird thing done with spaghetti in Africa is the Ethiopian way of eating it. They eat spaghetti in tomato sauce but the whole thing is served on an injera (very thin pancake made of teff wheat, with a sour taste because the dough is left to ferment for a few days). See pic related for an example.

>adding tomato to ceviche makes it mexican
The Mexican ceviche is not simply a tomato on top of the "original" recipe though. Not only is the tomato incorporated into the dish, other ingredients are also substituted from the south American variant due to differing availability. For example, in Peru (claims to have invented it), they also add hot peppers that Mexicans did not traditionally have access to.
>adding cream to carbonara makes it british/american
It's still Italian with cream. Yes, Italians did make it with cream themselves (albeit less commonly) despite what LARPing purists would have you believe, there are published Italian recipe books that instruct adding cream.

>>18899481
Similar experience here. I tried the much-touted Subway roast beef sub. Supposedly, according to social media posts that were "totally genuine and not paid-for marketing", it was a good fast food item enjoyed by many.
I ordered the sandwich and received what appeared to be a disheveled wad of paper, perhaps something to toss in the refuse bin. However, I was assured that my supposedly tasty treat was inside.
I followed the instructions and, upon removing the many layers of questionable wrapping material, was met with what appeared to be a "food-related item" that suffered a tumble down a set of stairs before being stomped under a steel toe boot.
Now, I'm not one to decry fast food presentation differing from advertisements, they all do it. But this seemed to be crossing the line. Nevertheless, I knew that presentation wasn't everything, so I carried on. I picked up the scrambled mass and, upon bringing it to my mouth, was hit with a pungent aroma that seemed to seat itself in the back of my sinus. Tears welled in my eyes as I opened my mouth and took my first (and only) bite. I tasted nothing upon entry. I tasted nothing upon the first bite of the chew. I chewed thrice more before "flavor" made itself known. It was not a welcome one. I have never had the displeasure of chewing on an old dishrag that had been dropped and forgotten behind a restaurant dishwasher, but this must have been its closest "edible" imitation.
I let the chewed mass fall from my mouth, back into the so-called "wrapper", letting it dribble upon the supposed "sandwich". I went to the nearest drug store and bought mouth wash - it took 5 cycles to rinse out the taste. Unfortunately, the pungent aroma that had seated itself in my sinus would persist for hours.

It was not until I stopped at my local Arby's restaurant and ordered a Roast Beef Sandwich that I had would have a sandwich worthy of the day. And a much-enjoyed one, at that. I highly recommend everyone try Arby's Roast Beef.

>>18899622
Too much volume on your dough. It looks more like bread than a pizza dough. You are probably not stretching it thin enough. Additionally, you should use enough dough that it reaches the edges of your pan. The appeal of pan pizza versus using a stone is the toppings all the way to the edge and the crispy cheese, in my opinion. If you are just going to make a normal pizza in a pan, use a stone instead.

Personally, I recommend switching from cast iron to a regular 9-inch cake pan, oiling it(season the oil if you please), then placing a thinner dough in and making sure it goes from edge to edge completely. Then you can just cover it all the way across with sauce, cheese, and toppings.

>>18898300
These look better…did you melt cheese? By salamder I mean essentially a broiler, where there is a heat source that is on top of food. Place cheese on buns, place under heat for 30 seconds, wala. By flattop I mean a flat metal cooktop with heat underneath that provides a large and consistently heated cook area. Place buns, inside facing up, on flattop or pan, put cheese on and cover, wait one minute and wala. Alternatively you can absolutely put cheese directly on a well seasoned and lightly oiled pan, then put the bread on top that. Use a fish spatula to get it off the cook top…griddled cheese is amazing. Wala

Here's my tip for this situation, which I have been in (and gotten laid in).
Pre-make a chocolate dessert in tumblers/wine glasses at home. I went with layered mascarpone, chocolate mousse and ganache with crushed amaretti biscuits. I happened to have some nice heavy Old Fashioned glasses to use but anything approx that size is fine. Practice if you need to at home, and transport them in a cooler bag with some freezer blocks or ice.
Cook whatever you like at her home. Something simple like pasta with any one-pot sauce, aglio e olio and mushrooms, whatever. Presentation is not THAT important and in fact a home-cooked charm is more useful. If you feel flush with cash pick a more ritzy ingredient or two to highlight (steaks can work, or fancy cheeses, or the like). The dessert will be buying you the majority of the brownie points and you know it's good before you walk in the door. Pressure is off. Use the opportunity to get your James Bond on and talk to her while you work.

posts.com:
Steak is hard to fuck up, get some nice steaks make sure to bring copper/ steel pan for searing and another for oven. Take steaks off of oven and and then chop a shallot and throw into pan you cooked steak with. Let them roast on medium heat for a while while scraping the pan with a wooden spoon. Then deglazing with 2 cups of red wine, while still scraping pan. Reduce to a third then pour sauce through a metal colindar into a bowl throw away shallot remains. Then pour strained sauce through a cheesecloth into a bowl. Beat a tb of warm butter into it. Pour over steak or set aside in nice bowl

posts.com:
kraft dinner casserole.

1 box kraft macaroni and cheese
1/2 of a package mini smoked sausages
about a quarter to 3rd of a bag of frozen mixed vegetables
1/4 cup milk
1/4 cup butter
salt

boil water. salt up the water, the normal amount for making pasta. when it comes to a boil throw in the frozen veggies. cut the little smokies in half. when the water returns to boiling (the frozen veggies will cool it a bit) throw in the macaroni from the mac and cheese and the sausages. cook the amount of time it says on the box. then drain everything, take pot off heat, after draining toss back in the pot and mix in the milk, cheese sauce powder, and butter. stir vigorously and then let sit 5 minutes. serve.

>>18893400
All of these people are out of their minds. Make a stew the day before. Make sure it tastes great, and it will be better the second day.

Also the day before, make smashed potatoes with a shit ton of butter and herbs. You literally just take small potatoes, a bit bigger than a golf ball, boil them until you can smash them in a kitchen towel. Melt half a stick of butter with salt and herbs in a cast iron pan, stack the potatoes in, then do the same melted butter, salt, pepper, herbs on top. Bake until slightly al dente, make sure it tastes great, wrap in foil, refrigerate.

Then just grab basic salad ingredients and wine. The next day when you get there, all you do is pop the oven on to 350, put the stew and potatoes in, find plates, pop open the wine, then banter while slicing tomatoes, maybe crumbling some cheese then tossing in a drizz of balsamic (that you brought) hopefully with a bit of her salt and oil if it's not rancid.

This is how to do it. Take all variables out of the equation. You already know the main stuff is good. All you have to do is put together a salad, drink wine, then plate it all up. This way you can use all of your mental energy trying to appear like you're not autistic.

I think the sheer number of desserts that require raw egg is really a testament to how safe they are to eat. Studies show only 1 in 30,000 eggs even has a salmonella problem. Healthy chickens with lots of sun exposure aren’t going have much salmonella to pass on to their eggs.

Just know that a healthy body is equipped to fight bacteria on its own. No matter what we eat, whether it’s raw or cooked, we encounter bad bacteria all the time (like on vegetables, for instance). The trick to avoiding salmonella in eggs is buying them fresh and using them in the right amount of time.

Raw eggs, as opposed to cooked, are packed with healthy protein and a variety of vitamins, minerals, and loads of vitamins like A, D, B2, B6, B9, B12, iron, and zinc. Not to mention omega 3 and 6 fatty acids, making them a great food in a healthy diet. When eggs are used raw they retain all of this natural goodness. When cooked, some of the omegas and vitamins are retained, but at least 1/4 are lost in the cooking process.

>>18897372
Nice, post recibe please.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18899006
5 taters
2 cups sour cream
3/4 stick of butter
6 green onions
1 tsp salt
1/2 tsp pepper
garlic powder to taste
8g of cheese (i used a Mexican cheese blend, some mozzarella, and a little asiago and parmesan)
boil potatoes till they're partway cooked, then shred them once they're cooled.
melt the butter and add in chopped green onions, salt, and pepper, then cook a lil bit and put in a bowl with the sour cream. add the garlic powder and mix around till they're all incorporated well, then mix in your cheese. butter a casserole dish and put in the potatoes and the cheese mix, make sure to mix everything together well. put in your oven (you should preheat it) at 350°F and bake it for 45 minutes to an hour.

>shred cheese, put in on a dehydrator (you'll want a fruit tray or so below to catch the oil, unless you have a nicer unit with a built in drip catch)
>blend or pulverize using what you have at hand
>mix up flour, corn flour/meal, butter, salt (MSG if you have it, add garlic and any other spices you want), refrigerate til cool or oven is preheated
>begin preheat oven to 350
>remove from fridge chop into cheeto sized fingerlings
>roll around in powdered cheese

>>18889571
I have the NS-LHC05XT, which is the Indian model. The Zojirushi in your picture is the NS-LGCO5XB which is the American model. The difference is that one has a jasmine rice button and the other has a steel cut oats button.

You list 3-cup size as a con, but actually it's a pro. Unless you have a family you'll never use all 3 cups. Keep in mind that it's talking about dry cups -- that's 1900 calories of rice. You're really gonna eat more than that in one sitting?

If you're not gonna eat more than that in one sitting, the smaller cup size is actually better than the bigger cup size. 1 cup of rice cooks better in the 3-cup pot than in the 5-cup pot. That's because less of it is "on the bottom" and more of it is "in the middle." It also stays more steamed since it's more cozy. I bought that one specifically because it's the smallest pot cooker I could find and it's a phenomenal device.

>>18892395
All rice (white, brown, wild) short grain, medium grain, long grain) absorbs the same amount of water proportionately. The only difference in cooking is time, because brown and wild rice need longer cooking time than white rice. This longer cooking time means more evaporation occurs, which is why it needs more water at the start.

So rice cookers still aren’t needed if you just have knowledge and measure the water properly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18896264
8 cups water
2 lbs boneless skinless chicken thighs

2 yellow onions (diced)
1 green bell pepper (diced)
4 stalks celery (diced)

1 tbsp cajun magic
1 tbsp chicken base

>roux
2/3 cup canola or grapefruit oil
3/4 cup flour

1 lb andouille, chopped

1/2 tsp Thyme
3 bay leaves
1 tbsp minced garlic
1 tbsp Tony Chachere
28 oz whole tomatoes, chopped+drained

Boil chicken thighs in water for 1 hr minimum. Remove chicken from water with tongs and shred with forks, add cajun magic+chicken base to water and put shredded chicken back in.

Make roux with vegetable oil+flour. ~20 minutes on medium-low heat until roux achieves a dark chocolate color is about right.

Add chopped veg (onion+bell pepper+celery) to roux and stir ~5 minutes until onion is translucent. Spoon roux+veg mix into broth with chicken.

Chop andouille into half moons and fry for ~5 minutes. Drain and place sausage into broth with roux+veg+chicken.

Dice tomatoes. Drain. Place tomatoes, thyme, bay leaves, garlic, Tony Chachere's into broth with roux+veg+chicken and let simmer for an hour minimum.

voila

>>18896264
This gumbo went as follows...

1x yellow onion diced
Half a bulb of celery diced (4-6 stalks)
2x bellpeppers diced
Whole chicken quartered with skin removed
Andouille sausage sliced into rounds
Garlic diced
Quart of chicken broth
2 cups of white wine
(I would normally add hot peppers but I didnt have any)

Roux is approx 2:1 fat to flour. (I used leftover chicken fat, beef tallow and then some olive oil. Bacon grease works too.)
~1 cup oil/fat

I stirred my roux on a medium heat for ~30 min until dark.

I threw in the onions and celery first until softened. Then I added the bell pepper, garlic and a ~1 Tbsp of Chicken better than bouillon.

Then I added in the chicken broth and wine. Bring to a boil and add chicken (raw) and andouille. Lower heat to medium low.

I seasoned with cajun seasoning, salt, pepper, paprika, seminole swamp seasoning, hot sauce, worcestershire and other things to taste.

Serve over rice.

My dad was friends with Paul Prudhomme, he was a cool guy, he didn't keep secrets and helped my dad get his restaurant started
If you're not going to use okra you can add one teaspoon of flour to the roux right at the end for extra thickening without affecting the flavor or color
If you're in a hurry, you can bring the fat up to its smoke point and add in all the flour at once

*carefully*

You can make a chocolate roux in a couple of minutes that way, but have your trinity good to go because you have to stop the roux from burning
Trinity, stir a minute or two + cold stock

Few more pointers:

>Street vendors are okay but again, make sure they have a line of people eating at them.

>Don't drink water unless it's in a bottle even if you're eating at a nice place. In fact I'd recommend not drinking water at all while you're over there and instead drink a beer and then just drink water bottles once you leave.

>Don't eat seafood if you're in an area that's landlocked or very far away from the ocean.

>If you're in Mazatlán, Veracruz, or Ensenada you're a damn fool if you don't eat the seafood there. Ensenada especially is like the seafood capital of the world. The lobster there is the best I've ever had.
